Introduction

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular tumor that is strongly associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) as well as HIV.  It manifests as violaceous cutaneous and mucosal lesions and can involve internal organs.  There are 4 primary forms of KS:



  • AIDS-associated (epidemic) KS
  • Classic KS
  • Endemic (African) KS
  • Iatrogenic (immunosuppression-related) KS


AIDS-associated KS is the most common and can be aggressive, particularly in untreated or poorly controlled HIV infection.

Pathophysiology



HHV-8 infects vascular and lymphatic endothelial cells, causing them to differentiate into a mixed phenotype thought to increase oncogenic potential.  The viral genome also contains several oncogenes that cause endothelial proliferation (eg, inhibit cell cycle regulation and apoptosis), thus promoting tumorigenesis.  In addition, HHV-8 induces production of angiogenic and inflammatory cytokines, creating a favorable environment for cell growth.

Risk factors

AIDS-associated (epidemic) KS



  • KS is the most common malignancy seen in patients with HIV.  Most cases arise in those with CD4+ cell counts <200/mm3 (considered an AIDS-defining malignancy), but all patients with HIV are at elevated risk.
  • Because HHV-8 is most common in men who have sex with men, these individuals account for the majority of cases.  However, patients who contract HIV by another mechanism (eg, intravenous drug use) may also develop the disease.

Classic KS



  • Classic KS is most commonly seen in elderly men of Mediterranean or eastern European descent.

Endemic (African) KS



  • Endemic (African) KS is seen in sub-Saharan Africa, particularly in areas of high HHV-8 prevalence.  Other environmental factors (eg, soil type) may contribute.
  • Both HIV-positive and HIV-negative individuals can be affected.  This form can affect younger individuals, including children.

Iatrogenic KS



  • Iatrogenic KS develops in patients on immunosuppressive therapy (eg, after organ transplantation).  The degree and duration of immunosuppression are critical factors.

Corticosteroids



With any form of KS, corticosteroid use can worsen existing lesions or cause new KS lesions. 

Pathology



Histopathology of KS characteristically shows a proliferation of spindle-shaped endothelial cells forming slit-like vascular spaces with inflammation (

image 1
).  The abnormal vascular spaces are leaky, allowing red blood cell extravasation.  Hemosiderin deposition, inflammation, and blood vessel formation contribute to the violaceous color of the lesions.  In advanced cases, lesions may infiltrate deeper tissues, including mucosa, lymphatics, and internal organs.

Clinical presentation



The hallmark of KS is violaceous cutaneous or mucosal lesions, with some differences in pattern and severity depending on the type of KS (

).

AIDS-associated (epidemic) KS



  • HIV-associated KS typically begins as flat, purple patches that resemble a bruise.  The lesions may become large and confluent and are often bilateral and symmetric.  Over time, they evolve into violaceous, red, or brown papules (
    image 2
    ).  Pain, pruritus, and necrosis are rare.
  • Lymphadenopathy distal to the lesions (eg, groin, axilla) is common due to lymphatic obstruction by the tumor.
  • Lesions can also develop on the mucosal membranes of the face (eg, palate) and genitals.
  • Lesions frequently spread internally to involve the lungs (eg, cough, dyspnea, hemoptysis, reticular/nodular opacities on imaging, violaceous endobronchial macules/papules on bronchoscopy) or gastrointestinal tract (eg, bleeding, obstruction, hemorrhagic nodules on endoscopy) and may be life-threatening.
  • Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus inflammatory cytokine syndrome can also occur, presenting in patients with a high tumor burden and viral activity, with fever, neuropathy, swelling, as well as gastrointestinal and respiratory manifestations, along with elevated inflammatory markers (eg, C-reactive protein) and other laboratory abnormalities.
  • Patients frequently have other symptoms (eg, weight loss, diarrhea) of severe HIV infection at presentation.


AIDS-associated KS is a common and aggressive form of KS in the setting of untreated or advanced HIV infection.

Classic KS



Classic KS tends to follow an indolent course, predominantly affecting the skin of older men (age >60) from Mediterranean or central/eastern European backgrounds.  Extracutaneous involvement seems to be less common than in AIDS-associated (epidemic) KS.  It tends to not significantly influence survival.

Endemic (African) KS



Endemic KS is more common in sub-Saharan Africa, where HHV-8 prevalence is more widespread.  It tends to be aggressive in children, with lymphadenopathy and visceral involvement.  In adults, lesions are more likely to present similarly to classic KS but with a higher propensity for lymph node and visceral involvement.

Iatrogenic KS



KS is also common in patients on high-dose immunosuppressive therapy after organ transplantation.  Those who develop the malignancy usually do so within the first year of therapy.  The cutaneous lesions are similar to those seen with other forms of KS.  Patients who develop KS after organ transplantation are at high risk for visceral lesions, primarily in the lung or gastrointestinal tract.

Diagnosis



KS is often diagnosed based on clinical appearance, particularly in patients with known risk factors such as HIV infection or immunosuppression.  Violaceous cutaneous or mucosal lesions are highly suggestive.  Biopsy should be used to confirm the diagnosis, especially in those with atypical presentations.  HHV-8 can be detected via PCR or immunohistochemistry in lesional tissue.



Chest imaging (x-ray or CT scan) should be obtained in patients with suspected pulmonary involvement and may show pulmonary reticular or nodular opacities, occasionally with pleural effusion, and lymphadenopathy.



Endoscopy may be indicated in patients with gastrointestinal symptoms to visualize and biopsy KS lesions in the gastrointestinal tract.

Differential diagnosis



  • Bacillary angiomatosis (
    image 3
    ):  These lesions caused by Bartonella species (gram-negative rods that are slow-growing and fastidious) are commonly seen in immunosuppressed individuals. Although bacillary angiomatosis lesions are highly vascular, they typically begin as small, red/purple papules that grow into friable, pedunculated lesions.  Furthermore, fever and other systemic symptoms are often present.  Biopsy helps differentiate between bacillary angiomatosis and KS.
  • Angiosarcoma:  This rare, aggressive malignancy of endothelial cells is histologically distinct from KS due to anaplastic endothelial cells and an aggressive growth pattern.
  • Melanoma:  Amelanotic melanoma can mimic KS but can be distinguished with immunohistochemical markers such as S-100 or HMB-45.

Management

AIDS-associated (epidemic) KS



  • First-line treatment for HIV-associated KS is initiation of antiretroviral therapy (ART), which restores the immune response against HHV-8 and often results in spontaneous remission.
  • Local therapy (eg, intralesional chemotherapy) is sometimes offered for cosmetic reasons.
  • Systemic chemotherapy (eg, doxorubicin, paclitaxel) is usually reserved for those who have extensive lesions or progressive disease while on ART.

Classic, endemic, and iatrogenic KS



  • For classic KS, localized treatments such as excision or radiation are usually sufficient.  Systemic therapy is rarely needed.
  • For endemic KS, surgery and local therapy are primary modalities.
  • For iatrogenic KS, reducing or discontinuing immunosuppressive therapy often leads to regression of lesions, although there are risks (eg, organ rejection in transplant patients).

Complications



  • Pulmonary complications:  Pulmonary KS can lead to respiratory failure due to airway obstruction, pleural effusion, or alveolar hemorrhage.
  • Gastrointestinal complications:  Gastrointestinal KS may cause bleeding, obstruction, or perforation, particularly in advanced disease.
  • Lymphedema:  Infiltration of the lymphatic system leads to chronic lymphedema, especially in the lower extremities or genitalia.
  • Superimposed infections:  Secondary infections can complicate ulcerated KS lesions, particularly in immunosuppressed individuals.

Prognosis



The prognosis of KS varies based on the type and the patient's immune status.  AIDS-associated KS has seen dramatic improvements in prognosis with the introduction of ART.  In patients who respond to ART, KS lesions often regress or stabilize, improving survival rates.  However, patients with disseminated disease or severe immunosuppression have a worse prognosis.  Classic KS tends to have an indolent course.  Endemic and iatrogenic KS can be aggressive.

Summary



KS is a vascular tumor associated with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) and often occurs in individuals with compromised immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS.  The 4 primary types of KS include AIDS-associated, classic, endemic, and iatrogenic.  AIDS-associated KS is common and can be aggressive, often presenting as violaceous cutaneous or mucosal lesions.  The pathogenesis involves HHV-8 infection of endothelial cells, leading to abnormal proliferation and angiogenesis.  Risk factors include HIV infection, immunosuppression, and certain geographic regions.  The diagnosis is typically based on clinical presentation and confirmed by biopsy.  Treatment varies depending on the type and severity and may involve antiretroviral therapy, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or surgery.  Complications of KS can include pulmonary and gastrointestinal involvement, lymphedema, and secondary infections.
